currencies.name: US Dollar
currencies.summary: USD caught between blowout NFP (130k vs exp 65k) pushing first Fed cut to July and BLS revisions (-862k) raising sustainability concerns. Sector concentration in job gains (Healthcare, Government, Leisure) limits breadth. Soft Retail Sales (0.0%), weak ADP (6.5k), and CPI miss (0.2% vs exp 0.3%) keep dovish Fed narrative alive. Trade uncertainty (Trump USMCA exit rumors, Iran deal optimism) adds volatility. Dollar remains vulnerable to data disappointments despite headline strength.

currencies.name: Euro
currencies.summary: EUR consolidates sub-1.1900 as USD weakness provides modest support but domestic catalysts remain limited. ECB calls for more EU debt to fund defense and climate spending, signaling fiscal expansion ahead. German ifo Business Climate (Tuesday) will test sentiment after weak GDP and Manufacturing data. China dairy tariffs (11.7% on EU products effective Feb 13) add trade friction. EUR benefits from Dollar weakness but lacks independent bullish drivers. Structural positioning remains defensive.

currencies.name: British Pound
currencies.summary: GBP under sustained pressure after weak GDP (0.7% y/y vs exp 1.1%) and Manufacturing Production (-0.5%). Business Investment fell -2.7% q/q, signaling domestic demand weakness. Political uncertainty persists despite Cabinet support for Starmer. BoE pricing remains dovish after 5-4 split in February, with April cut still on the table. GBP underperforms across the board, with GBP/AUD, GBP/JPY, GBP/CHF all showing bearish momentum. Structural weakness dominates near-term outlook.

currencies.name: Japanese Yen
currencies.summary: JPY rallies sharply post-Takaichi landslide election victory as markets price higher BoJ hike odds (~60% March). USD/JPY reversal from 157 to 153 sparked intervention speculation and carry trade unwind. Takaichi's pro-growth, hawkish fiscal stance contrasts with prior weak-JPY messaging, surprising markets. Safe-haven bid during AI disruption selloff (Thursday) reinforced strength. BoJ policy meeting (March 19) looms as critical catalyst. JPY outperforms all G10 peers except CHF during risk-off episodes.

currencies.name: Australian Dollar
currencies.summary: AUD reclaims 0.71 for first time in 3 years on hawkish RBA rhetoric. Deputy Governor Hauser: inflation too high, bank will do what needed. Assistant Governor Hunter: labor market remains bit tight. RBA reinforces inflation fight not finished after 25bp hike to 3.85%. AUD reacted to risk sentiment with choppy trading, hit hard during Thursday's AI disruption selloff but recovered Friday. Gold above $5,000/oz provides commodity support. Wednesday CPI (m/m, y/y, Trimmed Mean) critical for RBA path.

currencies.name: Canadian Dollar
currencies.summary: CAD under persistent pressure as Trump considers exiting USMCA, with US Trade Adviser Navarro describing agreement as flawed. Mexican President Sheinbaum denies withdrawal was raised privately, but trade uncertainty dominates. BoC minutes view 2.25% as stimulative but appropriate, acknowledging USMCA review as downside risk. Oil fell sharply Thursday (-3% to $62.84) as IEA trimmed 2026 demand forecast and OPEC Plus supply headlines resurfaced. CAD remains vulnerable to trade rhetoric and soft oil.

currencies.name: Swiss Franc
currencies.summary: CHF strengthened during Thursday's AI disruption equity selloff, reflecting pronounced flight to quality. SNB Vice Chairman Schlegel reinforced high threshold for returning to negative rates, reducing easing speculation. January inflation -0.1% m/m (0.1% y/y) remains extremely low but within SNB's Q1 range. Alphabet issued 3.0455 billion CHF debt, generating structural support through funding flows. CHF rallied vs most G10 peers apart from JPY during risk-off, but remains unattractive on carry in stable risk environments.

currencies.name: New Zealand Dollar
currencies.summary: NZD largely passenger to USD swings and global risk tone, with limited domestic catalysts. Held up better than AUD during Thursday's risk-off episode, reflecting less aggressive carry trade unwind. Trump-Xi trade truce reportedly extended 1 year, reducing immediate tariff risk. RBNZ meeting Wednesday critical: prior inflation persistence has reduced confidence in aggressive easing path. High-beta profile means NZD benefits when equities and pro-cyclical flows are stable. Vulnerability remains to external growth scares.
